results.content: Real good. Thorough explanations with an emphasis on conveying pertinent details. My only "would of liked to have.." would have been a "real world example" for each section of the operators.

results.content: I recommend this course to anyone who wants to learn more about RxJS and Reactive Programming. At the end of it you may still be confused in some areas, but you will gain some knowledge that will help you learn Rx even further from other resources.

results.content:
It's just examples without any challenges for the student to complete. Challenges offer students the opportunity to put what they are learning into practice to solve actual problems. This course is just a bunch of abstract examples, with the instructor saying "You could use [this feature] to do something like this...". It's difficult to see how you could actually apply it in a real project. 
Also, the instructor doesn't clearly explain what he is doing, but rather defers explanation until afterwards. I don't find this helpful.
results.content_html:
It's just examples without any challenges for the student to complete. Challenges offer students the opportunity to put what they are learning into practice to solve actual problems. This course is just a bunch of abstract examples, with the instructor saying "You could use [this feature] to do something like this...". It's difficult to see how you could actually apply it in a real project.
Also, the instructor doesn't clearly explain what he is doing, but rather defers explanation until afterwards. I don't find this helpful.

results.content: Helpful but the videos should be more planned.  The examples seem to come off the top of his head without much (if any) preplanning or cuing for the student.  The code simply lands on the page and it's often up to the viewer deduce its relevance and operation.  When the instructor takes the time to diagram concepts, he is extremely effective.  I wish more of the course had that planning.

results.content:
The lecturer has just dropped out of sight. He no longer answers questions. The course does have SOME value. The course has a topic that needs more explanation than the lecturer provides. Starting off with the build process may be good or bad. Good, if you are able to do the build. Bad, if you cannot. Because of incomplete information from the lecturer/tutorial, I had some problems that were ultimately resolved by other people taking this course, not the lecturer. 

I had other questions, but the lecturer has not responded to me or other people posting other questions.

My thinking is that if a video tutorial answers one question, the video is worth the $10 that I paid for it. This video has answered several questions for me for now and the future. So I am NOT going to ask for a refund, but I will let future customers know what they are in for if they purchase this course.

results.content:
It was a nice technical intro and I particularly liked the motivational aspects.

But the audio volume is shamefully low. When my interface volume and my computer volume are at 100, I should be able to listen along in the adjacent room. It should be uncomfortably loud sitting in front of the computer. You should amplify and republish at 175%-200% of the current volume. Currently, it's useless to attempt watching while travelling (auto, train, or in flight).

results.content: Its a good course, and I can recommend it. I would've hoped for a more comprehensive explanation of the reactive programming paradigm and the streams in it, though. Currently it goes through the basic idea of RX and dives deep into RxJS methods.
results.content_html: Its a good course, and I can recommend it. I would've hoped for a more comprehensive explanation of the reactive programming paradigm and the streams in it, though. Currently it goes through the basic idea of RX and dives deep into RxJS methods.

results.content: I've been trying to learn RxJS and this course helped me quite a bit. The instructor is very good and the section on operators is gold! Another thing is that this course uses the latest version of RxJS (v5) and the instructor goes into explaining where we should look for docs on this latest version (I was guilty of sometimes checking the wrong docs for v5, which was really confusing). One thing I missed is the use of more practical examples like building a real project, but that's probably content for another course. And make sure you're fairly comfortable with javascript (including ES6 features) or programming in general before jumping in.
results.content_html: I've been trying to learn RxJS and this course helped me quite a bit. The instructor is very good and the section on operators is gold! Another thing is that this course uses the latest version of RxJS (v5) and the instructor goes into explaining where we should look for docs on this latest version (I was guilty of sometimes checking the wrong docs for v5, which was really confusing). One thing I missed is the use of more practical examples like building a real project, but that's probably content for another course. And make sure you're fairly comfortable with javascript (including ES6 features) or programming in general before jumping in.

results.content:
sorry, explanations were a little bit too chaotic for me, it was really hard to built a reasonable system in the head. even little mistakes brought a lot of confusions, because when i see smth unclear, i pause the video and try to understand for quite a long time. giving up, i unpause video and then it appears that it was just a mistake or typo. this brings frustration. 
also, i find the explanations a little bit confusing. i had to go over a quick overview from free youtube video and then come here to make things clear in my head. 
The manual vanila JS examples of RxJS operators before showing the RxJS operators themselves didn't make things easier for me, vice versa. But maybe it was only for me.
Still, thank you for your effort. i really liked the example with the drag-n-drop in the last section, i think that if course have move such examples from the real life - it would be much practical
Thanks again.

results.content: Overall, the course was excellent. I do have two recommendations. 1. At times, the instructor seemed to be "shooting-from-the-hip". A more scripted approach would help to alleviate this. 2. The final example (drag-and-drop), while very good, perhaps needed a more detailed explanation. I think it would have been great if the code was walked through visually, as some people (me included) learn more visually. As the instructor stated, he's very familiar with this type of code. With that said, I'd definitely recommend this course to a friend or colleague.
results.content_html: Overall, the course was excellent. I do have two recommendations. 1. At times, the instructor seemed to be "shooting-from-the-hip". A more scripted approach would help to alleviate this. 2. The final example (drag-and-drop), while very good, perhaps needed a more detailed explanation. I think it would have been great if the code was walked through visually, as some people (me included) learn more visually. As the instructor stated, he's very familiar with this type of code. With that said, I'd definitely recommend this course to a friend or colleague.

results.content: Great course. I wanted to make use of redux-observable for managing async operations in a react native project. The docs suggest being familiar with Rxjs. This course got me more than just familiar with it. Thanks!
results.content_html: Great course. I wanted to make use of redux-observable for managing async operations in a react native project. The docs suggest being familiar with Rxjs. This course got me more than just familiar with it. Thanks!

results.content:
Very cool intermediate course that helps understanding dev setup, principles behind rx and then dives into the nitty gritty of applying it.

In the end it felt dragging going through all those operators with small examples. I couldn't see where this would tie into a real world application.
The final example is great, but the instructor doesn't explain it much for someone who isn't experienced with rx. For him it's very easy to read to code and it feels "self-explanatory" but for people new to the topic it's not and they need more guidance.
results.content_html:
Very cool intermediate course that helps understanding dev setup, principles behind rx and then dives into the nitty gritty of applying it.

In the end it felt dragging going through all those operators with small examples. I couldn't see where this would tie into a real world application.
The final example is great, but the instructor doesn't explain it much for someone who isn't experienced with rx. For him it's very easy to read to code and it feels "self-explanatory" but for people new to the topic it's not and they need more guidance.

results.content:
Very knowledgeable tutor with bags of enthusiasm. Good balance of theory and code with nice use of the old way of approaching a problem alongside the new RxJS way. 

Setting up the tooling section is included but can be skipped so you can use the down load playground start project instead. I liked the tooling part as this gives more real world practice.

Fun course, excellent instructor and exciting technology!
results.content_html:
Very knowledgeable tutor with bags of enthusiasm. Good balance of theory and code with nice use of the old way of approaching a problem alongside the new RxJS way.

Setting up the tooling section is included but can be skipped so you can use the down load playground start project instead. I liked the tooling part as this gives more real world practice.

Fun course, excellent instructor and exciting technology!

results.content: Good content and made all the concept clear, Really its worth taking this course. Got to about the new paradigm and how to work on it.

results.content: Clearly and concisely explains how everything works in clean and easy-to-understand code.  Highly recommended.

results.content: In many aspects this course would have earned 5 points, but IMHO, there was too much time spent on stuff like gulp set-up and not enough time on RxJS operators. I would like to see more time invested in "real world" examples - not always the interval, timer and range.
results.content_html: In many aspects this course would have earned 5 points, but IMHO, there was too much time spent on stuff like gulp set-up and not enough time on RxJS operators. I would like to see more time invested in "real world" examples - not always the interval, timer and range.

results.content: Instructor is very knowledgeable, but I don't think that I could write an app using rxjs after this course without looking up for the simplest things in the docs. The biggest "hole" here is chaining all those methods, where in the end I don't know to what we subscribed for and why, how to use it in real app, etc. Examples aren't explained poorly but everything is too fast. This course is rather for intermediate/advanced folks.

results.content: Very thorough explanation of what’s going on. I have read a number of tutorials and docs on Rxjs and found them all hard to wrap my mind around, but the instructor does a great job of laying out the new paradigm by contrasting it with the old ideas that had been holding me back from understanding the true power of reactive programming!

results.content:
Amazing instructor, the overview of programming paradigms was completely on point. Cant wait to watch the rest of this course. 

...Now I did, and I'm still very happy with the course. The only thing that's missing is tests. However, testing RxJS v5 seems to be problematic at the moment. It is possible, but there is no perfect solution yet. RxJS TestScheduler looks promising, but still has major issues. I hope this course will be updated, once the RxJS community has agreed on a testing method.

Do not keep digressions in.

results.content:
Overall the course was great but I think there is room for improvement in:
1) The bootstrap process for the playground is too long and too subjective to the way the instructor likes to work. I followed along and decided to drop it and replace it for my workflow. So, my recommendation would be to abstract the user completely from the setup of the playground and jump right in to the matter at hand, which is rxjs.
2) I find that this is a very abstract subject, and all explanations are abstract. Abstract + abstract = confused =P
It would have been much more enlightening to go through more real life examples since that is how things tend to sink in in one's head.
results.content_html:
Overall the course was great but I think there is room for improvement in:
1) The bootstrap process for the playground is too long and too subjective to the way the instructor likes to work. I followed along and decided to drop it and replace it for my workflow. So, my recommendation would be to abstract the user completely from the setup of the playground and jump right in to the matter at hand, which is rxjs.
2) I find that this is a very abstract subject, and all explanations are abstract. Abstract + abstract = confused =P
It would have been much more enlightening to go through more real life examples since that is how things tend to sink in in one's head.

results.content: Great course for those who want to learn the basics of RxJS and Reactive Programming. You will end with lots of questions, without any examples, which you can use in your real projects, but with an understanding on what to do and where to go next.

results.content: The author has great competence but typing is sometimes too fast and the lectures itself are a little bit improvised at some points. Constant fast typing and re-typing caused quite some distractions for me. Would have been good if the lectures would have been tidied up after recording. Apart from this certainly a great course to start with rxjs.

results.content: Content is good but in my opinion it needs more js & html examples like the drag and drop. Because learning just observables wont get you anywhere until you really know how to apply them to your daily work in things like, form validation, user notifications, content update, etc.

results.content: Great course. Wish it was a bit longer because there is hardly any RXJS content on Udemy.
results.content_html: Great course. Wish it was a bit longer because there is hardly any RXJS content on Udemy.

results.content:
Started off strong.  My first foray into reactive programming and the early lectures did a good job in providing insight into reactive programming, it's justification and it's basic structure.

By the time we got to the lecture on Built-In Observables, I was lost.  I would stop the video, stare at the code and try to get my head around it.  I was only slightly successful.  What I couldn't do was begin to understand WHY I would ever be interested in some of the reactive pipelines and how or why they would be applicable in a real life application.  What does it mean to use Rx.Observable.empty() to return an observable even though "you don't want to return anything"?  Huh?  And that's a fairly easy one to reason about - - wait until you get to Subjects.

Sorry.  Maybe I'll re-run some of these lectures and try again.  But without being able to connect observable usage with real world functionality, making a good mental connection to this difficult technology will be... well... difficult.  A course that covered fewer concepts (i.e., fewer observables and operators) but did so by applying them to understandable programming scenarios would have been much more helpful to someone new at this technology.

Three and one-half stars from me.
results.content_html:
Started off strong. My first foray into reactive programming and the early lectures did a good job in providing insight into reactive programming, it's justification and it's basic structure.

By the time we got to the lecture on Built-In Observables, I was lost. I would stop the video, stare at the code and try to get my head around it. I was only slightly successful. What I couldn't do was begin to understand WHY I would ever be interested in some of the reactive pipelines and how or why they would be applicable in a real life application. What does it mean to use Rx.Observable.empty() to return an observable even though "you don't want to return anything"? Huh? And that's a fairly easy one to reason about - - wait until you get to Subjects.

Sorry. Maybe I'll re-run some of these lectures and try again. But without being able to connect observable usage with real world functionality, making a good mental connection to this difficult technology will be... well... difficult. A course that covered fewer concepts (i.e., fewer observables and operators) but did so by applying them to understandable programming scenarios would have been much more helpful to someone new at this technology.

Three and one-half stars from me.

results.content:
The material is really good and it I found it really helpful in understanding the reactive paradigm. 
The only reason I am giving this 3.5 stars is that the material is a bit outdated (at the time of this review RxJS 6 is out while the course uses RxJS 5. Finding the equivalent operators for RxJS6 is not hard though, it's a simple google search). Also, it uses gulp which is deprecated - I had to figure out a way to to the same with webpack instead which took a while.
results.content_html:
